statement.tex: %text Find a unit vector in the direction of $\ora{a}=\vector{3}{-2}{6}$. %

step.tex: %text $\ora{v_2}$ is the only unit vector among these. %
step.reason: %text A unit vector is one whose \underline{\text{magnitude is 1}}. Magnitude of a vector $\ora{v}=\vector{a}{b}{c}$ is given as $|\ora{v}|=\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}$. Of the given vectors, % \begin{align} |\ora{v_1}|&=\sqrt{1^2+\left(-\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^2+\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^2} =\sqrt{\dfrac{3}{2}}\\ {\bf |\ora{v_2}|}&=\sqrt{\dfrac{1}{3}+\dfrac{1}{3}+\dfrac{1}{3}} =1 \\ |\ora{v_3}|&=\sqrt{2^2+(-1)^2+(-1)^2}=\sqrt{6} \end{align} \\ %text only $\ora{v_2}$ is a unit vector. %

step.context: %text What could $\ora{a}=\vector{3}{-2}{6}$ be multiplied so the product is a unit vector in the same direction as $\ora{a}$? %
step.reason: %text If a vector $\ora{v}$ is divided by its magnitude, it results in a unit vector in the same direction as itself. For e.g. if $\ora{v}=\vector{a}{b}{c}$, dividing it by $|\ora{v}|=\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}$ results in unit vector $\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}}(\vector{a}{b}{c})$. Therfore in this particular problem, dividing $\ora{a}$ by $|\ora{a}|$ gives unit vector $\hat a$, which is % \begin{align} \hat{a}&=\dfrac{\ora{a}}{|\ora{a}|} =\dfrac{\vector{3}{-2}{6}}{\sqrt{3^2+(-2)^2+6^2}} \\ &=\dfrac{1}{7}(\vector{3}{-2}{6}) \end{align}
